title: Cat. 119.1  Tahitians, Flowers, and Leaves, 1899/1900
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Tahitians, Flowers, and Leaves, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile)  
1899/1900  
Only state  
Wood-block print in black ink on thin ivory laid Japanese paper; 104 × 183 mm (image), 123 × 215 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1951.36  
Guérin 77, Kornfeld 70  
For the verso, see fig. 119.1.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin carved interchangeable vignettes and headpieces to accompany the text of his self-published journal, Le sourire (The Smile). He used a small piece of coarsely grained wood, in contrast to the fine-grained boxwood used for Three People, a Mask, a Fox, and a Bird (cat. 111) and Fox, Busts of Two Women, and a Rabbit (cat. 120). As in his Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints (cats. 91–105), this wood likely derived from an indigenous source that Gauguin himself prepared for carving and printing.

Tahitians, Flowers and Leaves was never realized as a headpiece in any of the nine published issues of Le sourire. In the facsimile edition it is reproduced among a group of six wood-block prints, none of which appeared paired with text in any of the published issues of the journal.

The impression was printed in black ink.

The thin sheet of mitsumata (est.) paper presents a delicate laid and chain line pattern. There are small fibrous clumps and inclusions throughout. It is an absorbent Japanese paper that took the ink readily from the block, resulting in a soft, rich impression. The sheet is scissor cut along the right and bottom edges. In order to successfully print such a thin sheet, a more substantial secondary paper was likely used as a carrier to help facilitate lifting the mitsumata paper from the inked block. This contrasts with another impression in the Art Institute’s collection, which is printed on a harder, sized, Western wove paper (cat. 119.2).

104 × 183 mm (image); 123 × 215 mm (sheet)

The print is sound, stable condition.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Georges-Daniel de Monfreid (1856–1929), Paris.

Sold by Robert G. Michel, Paris, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1951.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Marcel Guérin, L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980), cat. 77 (ill.).

Per Amann, Paul Gauguin (Artline, 1987), pp. 66, 102 (ill.).

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), pp. 248–49, no. 70 (ill.).

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed in wood block, left, printed in white-line manner: Le / Sourire

Inscribed upper right, in graphite: G 7

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952), reproduced as pl. D, VI

Fiber analysis was conducted on Tahitian Carrying Bananas (cat. 98.2), and mitsumata fiber was confirmed. IPS Testing, Appleton, Wisc., report no. IPS 00592-15, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. Although Tahitian Carrying Bananas was the only print that was sampled and analyzed, visual examination of the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints (cats. 91–105) and various prints for Le sourire revealed that these works were also printed on the same type of paper. The appearance, tone, surface quality, weight, and even fiber distribution found in these papers are identical.

Marcel Guérin, L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980), cat. 77 (ill.).

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 119.1 Tahitians, Flowers, and Leaves, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile), 1899/1900.

fig. 119.1.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Tahitians, Flowers, and Leaves, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile) (1899/1900). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1951.36.

</section>
